===Hedonism===
 
===Hedonism===
−
[[Hedonism]] posits that the principal ethic is maximizing [[pleasure]] and minimizing [[pain]]. There are several schools of Hedonist thought ranging from those advocating the indulgence of even momentary desires to those teaching a pursuit of [[spiritual bliss]]. In their consideration of consequences, they range from those advocating [[self-gratification]] regardless of the pain and expense to others, to those stating that the most ethical pursuit maximizes all the pleasure and happiness for the most people.<ref name = "epsxlu">Sahakian, William S. & Sahakian, Mabel Lewis. ''Ideas of the Great Philosophers''. pg 37. Barnes and Noble Books (1993). ISBN 9781566192712.</ref>
+
[[Hedonism]] posits that the principal ethic is maximizing [[pleasure]] and minimizing [[pain]]. There are several schools of Hedonist thought ranging from those advocating the indulgence of even momentary desires to those teaching a pursuit of spiritual bliss. In their consideration of consequences, they range from those advocating [[self-gratification]] regardless of the pain and expense to others, to those stating that the most ethical pursuit maximizes all the pleasure and happiness for the most people.<ref name = "epsxlu">Sahakian, William S. & Sahakian, Mabel Lewis. ''Ideas of the Great Philosophers''. pg 37. Barnes and Noble Books (1993). ISBN 9781566192712.</ref>
